title: Uganda: 2010 Bomb Detonating Phones Got From Plaza
text:
Court also heard that he didn't issue him with a receipt since he was in a hurry. 
The witness said he knew Mr Luyima before as he also dealt in selling phones around town. 
How it happened 
"The day of July 9, 2010 began as any other normal day for me. But in the evening at around 7pm while I was closing my shop, I got a customer who wanted two cheap phones. I decided to attend to him," said the witness. 
He added: "I got a Nokia phone and I told him it would cost him Shs50,000 but he rejected it, saying it was expensive. He then said I should get him other cheaper ones which I did." 
The 51-year-old further told court that he did not see Mr Luyima again until after about one month when security operatives brought him to his shop. Mr Makubuya said the operatives also interrogated him but released him shortly after. 
But during cross-examination by defence lawyer Caleb Alaka, Mr Makubuya could not tell why he did not issue Mr Luyima with a receipt to prove that he had purchased the phones from him. 
The second witness of the day was Mr Francis Mugoga, a businessman and lecturer, who told court of how he lost three out of 11 friends he was with at Ethiopian Village Restaurant on that fateful day. He said six out of the 11 friends were Americans. 
Hearing continues today. 
Background 
During the early stages of the trial, the second prosecution witness, Mr Edris Nsubuga, told court of how phones that were used in the bomb mission were purchased from downtown. 
Mr Nsubuga also told court that he threw one of the phones in a pit latrine after the mission though the police retrieved it to assist in the investigations. Uganda
